title.narrative: TMT+ Entrepreneurship Education for Syrian Refugees in Kurdistan

description.narrative: . The entrepreneurship training programme targets the young Kurdish and refugee population (mainly Syrians) with entrepreneurial aspirations.

The Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (MoLSA) provides vocational skills training in six Vocational Training Centres (VTCs) in Kurdistan to adults aged 18 or older who did not complete compulsory education and who want to obtain some professional training. Less than 1 percent of adults each year participate in such training. Trainings often focus on a specific sector, such as hospitality or construction. Together with UNESCO, we did organize a one-time entrepreneurship project Fighting Youth Unemployment through Education for our TVET graduates in 2013. For this, 11 trainers at the different MoLSA VTC institutes were capacitated to deliver these trainings to youth. However, this was a one-time project only, and in general our students are not structurally capacitated to start their own business. Together with UNESCO, several curricula have been developed that connect to the needs in the labour market, for example in construction, IT, hospitality, and hairdressing. One module in these curricula focuses on entrepreneurship for the specific area of study. MoLSA does not yet provide a stand-alone entrepreneurship curriculum. We would welcome the initiative of an intensive entrepreneurship curricula that is sector-wide and as inclusive as possible (we especially struggle with female performance and their transition to the labour market in our VTCs). We do look forward bringing entrepreneurial skills development back to our centres as youth unemployment is an ever-growing problem within the country. . What we find most important in such a curriculum, is the assurance that students are truly able to become an entrepreneur and start their own business after completion of the programme. A strong linkage between the VTCs and private sector institutions such as financial institutes (who give micro-credit loans) is needed. We would like to achieve the implementation of this curriculum at our VTC in Erbil for the first time in 2021, if this is successful we aim to roll-out the curriculum in all six VTCs (also in Sulaimaniyah, Duhok, Soran, Garmiyan and Zakho).

With the TMT Plus project, we aim at increasing the entrepreneurial skills of youth in Kurdistan, targeting host community youth as well as youth with a refugee background. By developing entrepreneurial competences for these target groups we aim to: - Contribute to a private sector development through a growing number of MSMEs in Kurdistan, started by youth; - Increase the self-employment rate of host community and refugee youth in Kurdistan, building livelihoods and resilient communities; - Contribute to an increased cohesion among the refugee and host community by connecting the younger generation; Orange Knowledge Programme - Tailor-Made Training Plus 21/81 - Contribute to an inclusive educational offer for refugee students that removes barriers in access to and performance in education and their transition to the job-market.

title.narrative: % of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

title.narrative: The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.
